author: r.alxz
content: We integrated the 1559 blockchain tests today and ran into some issues with the `<,>` vs `<=,>=` boundaries, I added some more details here https://github.com/ethereum/tests/pull/837#issuecomment-849201825

author: sky.cactus
content: Is anyone planning on building a complex system for `minGasPremium` that miners use, or is everyone planning on just having a launch config variable for it (or perhaps repurposing the already existing `minGasPrice` config variable)?

author: p_bitfly
content: Yes we plan to dynamically adjust it to the MEV value of a block (trivial as MEV reward is known before adding any other tx)

author: barnabemonnot
content: it's known to the miner, but not to the user. would you consider adding transactions that may have set their premium below the "true" `minGasPremium` you have for the block? otherwise users would always need to bid the upper bound of the `minGasPremium` range to guarantee next-block inclusion

author: barnabemonnot
content: by this i mean, instead of setting dynamically `minGasPremium` block-to-block, would you consider using an optimistic average instead, that is updated less frequently?

author: p_bitfly
content: No as increases our risk of uncling a block

author: sky.cactus
content: What is the planned algorithm for this adjustment?  Just the `* 500,000,000` that was suggested previously?

author: sky.cactus
content: There is no upper bound.  We have seen MEV that is 100 ETH before.

author: sky.cactus
content: And in theory we may see even bigger in the future.

author: sky.cactus
content: (100 ETH MEV in a block using the simple algorithm is 50 nanoeth / gas)

author: fvictorio
content:
Hi, I synced geth with baikal and tried sending some 1559 txs but I'm not sure if they are being really being interpreted as 1559. Does anyone have an example of a correct 1559 tx payload?

(I'm not sure if this is the right channel to ask this, please let me know if it isn't)

author: fvictorio
content:
Here's the last tx I tried:

```
{ from: a, to: a, maxFeePerGas: "0x3c9aca00", maxPriorityFeePerGas: "0x100", gas: "0x10000", chainId: "0x66a", accessList: [] }
```

content: This is the tx: http://18.224.51.102:3000/tx/0x766fd0d81c788723263f94bef52aec5d658a4cdbad8ea99c7af25340d56468ae

author: fvictorio
content: If I then fetch the tx with `eth_getTransaction`, the type is 0x1 instead of 0x2. If I remove the `accessList`, it just shows as a legacy tx.

author: holiman
content: Then it's not a 1559 type

author: fvictorio
content: What should I change in the tx payload to make it a 1559?

author: holgerd77
content: We have now released London/EIP-1559 compatible versions of our libraries (in particular the EthereumJS VM and our Tx library), see https://github.com/ethereumjs/ethereumjs-monorepo/releases for a release overview.

author: holgerd77
content:
<@!130156954273316865> It is not really apparent what the resulting serialization format is from what you are posting as your transaction value input. And if feeding a tx library with a `maxPriorityFeePerGas` field will result in the creation of a 1559 tx is likely depending on the implementation.

With the `@ethereumjs/tx` library you can create a 1559 tx with `FeeMarketEIP1559Transaction.fromTxData()`, this will automatically result in a 1559 tx which you can then use to create the correct serialized tx payload with `tx.serialize()`. See the tx release notes from the link above for a more complete example.

Generally note that the tx payload format has changed with the introduction of typed txs, for 1559 it is e.g. `0x02 || rlp([chainId, nonce, maxPriorityFeePerGas, maxFeePerGas, gasLimit, to, value, data, access_list, signatureYParity, signatureR, signatureS])`, see the respective section in the EIP: https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1559#abstract

A tx payload now always starts with a first byte for the tx type. So if it is not `0x02` for 1559 tx, you can already see that your payload is malformed.

author: fvictorio
content: Yeah, I'm interested in the JSON-RPC interface because that's what we need to implement in Hardhat, so I'm trying to understand how geth implements that, and be able to experiment with it

author: holgerd77
content:
Hi everyone,
is there an RPC endpoint which I can publicly forward to other devs (and e.g. also promote here to <@!130156954273316865> for testing)? I know we have got 1-2 but doesn't want to just throw (half-)publicly in the ring here myself.

Would this be an RPC endpoint we could eventually also add to the baikal spec document https://github.com/ethereum/eth1.0-specs/blob/master/network-upgrades/client-integration-testnets/baikal.md and promote in the Ecosystem Developer calls? //cc <@!420951281910284289> <@!552133098075193354> 

Guess this would be helpful for ecosystem developers to test their stuff. ðŸ™‚
